title.narrative: Energy absorbing mooring systems: Risk-based investigation for high intensity typhoon conditions in China (MoTyph)

description.narrative: 1.Development of a risk-based engineering design envelope for wave energy converter mooring systems in high intensity (class 4/5) typhoon events. The specific aims are to i) derive statistical estimates of the key environmental design parameters (e.g. wave height, current and wind speed) and to subsequently ii) produce a risk-based map of typhoon risk zones for wave energy converters in the Chinese Sea. 2. Calculation of the hydrodynamic performance parameters for a heaving point absorber deployed in Chinese waters. The rationale is to utilise an existing device design, tested and deployed by the project partner, the National Ocean Technology Center (NOTC), China, which will be enhanced by integrating an energy absorbing mooring system. 3. Design, modelling and physical testing of energy absorbing mooring system incorporating novel hysteretic mooring components. The design shall improve both the extreme load response and the expected fatigue life of the mooring system and investigates novel line constructions using polymeric materials.

Wave energy technology in China could potentially contribute 13GW of installed power to the country's energy needs with particular benefit to coastal regions that have limited local energy resources. Commercial wave energy development in China is hampered by low wave power density levels between 2-7kW/m, an order of magnitude less than the UK, yet suffers on average from more than 10 high intensity typhoon events a year, causing extreme wind and wave conditions. This project aims to address the survivability of wave energy converters in Chinese waters during reoccurring high intensity typhoons. The research will explore the development of cost-effective mooring systems.
